SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Primary Sj√∂gren's syndrome (SS) with central nervous system involvement and antiphospholipid syndrome have been reported to mimic multiple sclerosis (MS)
SS has also been found in patients diagnosed with definite MS
PATIENTS AND METHODS: A Chinese lady developed multiple relapsing neurological events involving the brain and spinal cord from the age of 40 years
Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and spinal cord during acute relapses showed increased T2 signals and spinal cord edema
She later developed positive anti-nuclear antibody and anti-Ro autoantibody followed by sicca symptoms, confirming the diagnosis of SS
She died from aspiration pneumonia following pseudobulbar palsy shortly after SS was diagnosed
CONCLUSIONS: Patients with MS-like disease and autoantibodies should be carefully evaluated for other systemic autoimmune diseases as the treatment and prognosis differ from MS
In particular, sicca symptoms should be sought as they often go unnoticed by patients
This is especially important in Orientals in whom MS is relatively uncommon
